Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where they want, even if for the convenience of others they have to sit elsewhere. The Dutch express a sense of entitlement to sit where one must be obliged to be, thou shall sit there because I have established privileged first in, last out.

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to the hybrid fantasy world that director Andrew Niccol establishes. The film is a comforting reminder that we are not as lucky as Malo (Xavier Samuels), the film’s romantic lead, who happens to have been born with the ability to heal people with his touch.

After watching this movie, I couldn't help but notice the parallels between it and another film called America 3000. Both were very bad mid 1980's scifi movies that feature a girl who can't remember the language of her people, and her desire to find out where she came from. Both feature people in leather and sometimes gold one-piece body suits. The only difference was that America 3000 was darker and involved cannibals.

The only reason I am commenting is because I finally figured out why Dr. Cox was bald. Although we probably all realized it at the same time this week Dr. Cox is bald because he has Raynaud's syndrome. If you look carefully every time he is disgusted, annoyed, or stressed you can see his finger tips go white. His reaction in The My Two Dads Episode perfectly demonstrates it. Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie is pale by comparison to My Life To Live by Godard or Biancaneve by Cipriani and Ruggero Deodato. If one is new to Italian “cinema of the masses,” I would recommend Hello Brother or Midnight Dog.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is going to be criticized by some because it has very little action in it but I recommend it for what it is if you're a fan of either Joe Armstrong or ninjas because you're going to greatly enjoy it.
